title: Experts' hat tips for the Melbourne Cup
text:
Lauren Sams Luxury Editor Oct 23, 2019 — 9.52am Share

The first rule of hats is that one must always be worn at the races, says milliner Ann Shoebridge. Sure, Shoebridge has a vested interest in keeping the racing population well-hatted, but she insists it’s merely good manners – not to mention stylish. “I always think of the milliner Stephen Jones,” she says, “who says that hats are like the exclamation points of our outfits. Who doesn’t want that?”

As the spring racing carnival careens into town, the time is nigh to begin planning one’s style – including, of course, headwear. This season, says Shoebridge, the headband is a big trend, driven by the catwalks of Prada and Gucci.

The Anna headband in black and white would tick all the boxes at Derby Day.

“Headbands have been around for a few years now but this year they’ve really come into their own,” she says. “To be honest, at first I thought they were something of a gateway to a bigger hat but actually they’re a trend of their own. They’re a good way to show off your make-up and hair without detracting from your outfit, and they’re one size fits all, which is good if you’re shopping online.”

Hats are the ultimate accessory. Nothing finishes an outfit like a hat. — Mike Witt, Strand Hatters

Shoebridge, who has been creating millinery for 16 years and was the Australian finalist for Hat Designer of the Year in 2013, was inspired by 1960s Italian cinema for her own collection this season. There is the Anna, a soft black bow that falls like a fringe, the Marcello, a sunshine yellow sunhat tied with a bow under the chin, and the Claudia, a red-and-white broad brim hat that evokes a trattoria tablecloth – the most stylish one you’ve ever seen, of course.

Although Shoebridge doesn’t produce toppers for men – yet – she says it’s an area she is keen to explore. “Men wear hats more often than women,” she says. “It makes sense that they should wear them to the races.”

Cap off a suit with the right hat – straw Panamas, trilbys and fedoras are on trend for men. Jessica Shapiro

It’s a sentiment with which Mike Witt, owner of Sydney’s Strand Hatters, wholeheartedly agrees. “Hats are the ultimate accessory. Nothing finishes an outfit like a hat.”

Over the past few years, says Witt, there’s been a substantial increase in men looking for hatwear for the races. “It started with stylists coming in with suits and shoes and requesting hats to match for male clients, but now we see the men themselves come in. They’ve got the suits and they’re looking for something to finish the outfit.”
description: Take your inspiration from the catwalks to get ahead of the pack – headwear with flair is the name of the game.
